channel.title: #Tidyverse on R, it's OK I guess
channel.description: Recent content in #Tidyverse on R, it's OK I guess

item.title: Estimating sigma using quantiles
item.description: Packages There will be some R later, with some random number generation. I set the random number seed for reproducibility: library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.1.0 ✔ purrr 0.2.5 ## ✔ tibble 1.4.2 ✔ dplyr 0.7.8 ## ✔ tidyr 0.8.1 ✔ stringr 1.3.1 ## ✔ readr 1.1.1 ✔ forcats 0.3.0 ## ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() set.

item.title: Displaying grouped bar charts in ggplot
item.description: Introduction When you have two categorical variables to plot, grouped bar charts are one possible visualization. I learned something new about them today, from Hadley Wickham himself (well, via a tweet, anyway). As an example, let’s use some data from the Australian Institute for Sport: library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 2.2.1.9000 ✔ purrr 0.2.4 ## ✔ tibble 1.4.1 ✔ dplyr 0.7.4 ## ✔ tidyr 0.
